section.title: Process descriptor
section.para: A process descriptor file describes how users requests are handled by the controller component. The controller component should somehow interpret the textual query, such as ice cream recipe, and redirect it to an input component, then process intermediate result using filter components and finally display the result of processing to the user. How this flow is achieved is defined in the process descriptor file.
The process descriptor is an XML file, which specifies a script (usually in &beanshell;), which gets executed in response to each query and takes full control over the process of request processing.

section.title: Required elements of a process descriptor
section.para: Every process descriptor must contain the obligatory process element, which specifies its id. The identification string of a process is assigned by &carrot; project maintainer (because it is also used for assigning a locale-sensitive name).

The main part of a process descriptor consists of specification of how components are applied to the user request in order to produce certain output. This specification is expressed in &beanshell; code (see for an example).

section.title: Processing scripts
section.para: Active specification of how requests should be handled can be given in the form of a script. This script can be written in any language supported by the BSF project (Bean Scripting Framework), in particular a Java-like scripting language BeanShell or JavaScript.

The script has access to several global objects, which describe the current processing environment and user request. Namely, query object contains the user query and controller object allows the script to invoke processing using &carrot; components. Please consult examples present in the &cvs; for details.
